description: A body believed to be that of Miya Marcano, a 19-year-old college student who was reported missing last month, was found in Orlando, Fla., on Saturday, the authorities said.

title: Snoozefest
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays print introduction mentions that Trenton Charlson is 25, which makes me doubt time, frankly, because it feels as if we have been solving his Scrabbly grids forever. (Its actually been less than five years, but hes prolific  32 puzzles and counting.) Will Shortz makes note of the modern tools of crossword construction, software and programs that help create thrilling word lists like the one here, but thats really just part of the equation. Mr. Charlson says, I value the sort of X-factor that makes a puzzle feel playfully and distinctly human.

title: Mohib Ullah, 46, Dies; Documented Ethnic Cleansing of Rohingya
description: Mohib Ullah, a Rohingya community leader who believed in the power of data to confront the brutality of ethnic cleansing, died on Wednesday, shot by gunmen in a bamboo and tarp shelter in Kutupalong, Bangladesh, the worlds biggest refugee camp. He was 46.

title: Demonstrators March for Abortion Rights
description: Thousands participated across the United States in the fifth annual Womens March, specifically focused on abortion rights.

title: Whistle-Blower to Accuse Facebook of Contributing to Jan. 6 Riot, Memo Says
description: [Watch the Facebook hearing live.]

title: Quotation of the Day: Sights on U.S., Migrants Flood Perilous Jungle
description: We very well could be on the precipice of a historic displacement of people in the Americas toward the United States. When one of the most impenetrable stretches of jungle in the world is no longer stopping people, it underscores that political borders, however enforced, wont either.

title: Corrections: Oct. 3, 2021
description: The dance listings in the New Season issue on Sept. 19 misstated the dates of Caleb Teichers Swing Out at the Joyce Theater. Performances are Oct. 5-17, not Oct. 15-17.

title: Saturday Night Live Returns With a New President Biden
description: Its a new season at Saturday Night Live, which means new cast members  and, surprisingly, a new performer playing President Biden in his first episode on the show.

title: In a Surge of Military Flights, China Tests and Warns Taiwan
description: Record-breaking numbers of Chinese military planes probed the airspace near Taiwan over the weekend, prompting Taiwanese fighter jets to scramble and adding muscle to Beijings warnings that it could ultimately use force to take hold of the island.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SUNDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: It Was a Warm Sunday Afternoon at a Bar Near the Brooklyn Waterfront.
description: Dear Diary:

title: Military Bases Turn Into Small Cities as Afghans Wait Months for Homes in U.S.
description: FORT MCCOY, Wis.  In late August, evacuees from Afghanistan began arriving by the busload to the Fort McCoy Army base in the Midwest, carrying little more than cellphones and harrowing tales of their narrow escapes from a country they may never see again. They were greeted by soldiers, assigned rooms in white barracks and advised not to stray into the surrounding forest, lest they get lost.

title: Housing Boss Earns $1 Million to Run Shelters Despite a Troubled Past
description: Soon after Jack A. Brown III quit his job at a private prison company, his former employer accused him of fraud. A few years later, after Mr. Brown started a nonprofit to run halfway houses, a federal audit found that it had failed to deliver key services. The New York State comptroller concluded in another review that Mr. Brown had shown a disturbing pattern of ethical violations.

title: Trams, Cable Cars, Electric Ferries: How Cities Are Rethinking Transit
description: The roar of engines has long been part of the soundscape of a city.

title: How Texas Plans to Make Its House Districts Even Redder
description: The new district lines proposed by Texas Republicans aim to lock in the partys advantage in Washington over the next decade by building on a previously gerrymandered map.

title: In Praise of Rationality
description: RATIONALITYWhat It Is, Why It Seems Scarce, Why It MattersBy Steven Pinker

title: From Miriam Toews, a Tragicomedy About the Dysfunctional World of Adults
description: FIGHT NIGHT By Miriam Toews

title: How a Tip to Obituaries Breathed New Life Into a Decades-Old Mystery
description: As the junior member of The Timess Obituaries desk, I specialize in a duty more esoteric than writing or editing. I keep our list of recent deaths. Every tip from a Times reporter, every voice mail from a mourner and every entreaty from a publicist with a posthumous client  I record them all and ensure that each person they represent has a chance at whatever immortality newsprint offers.

title: Female Soccer Players Are Done Taking Abuse. Lets Stop Dishing It Out.
description: When will we stop treating women in sports as second-class citizens?

title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: 8 Things to Do in the Southwest This Fall
description: Fall is the onset of outdoor season in the Southwest, when birds return to winter in the mild temperatures, skies clear of the summer monsoons and color tours may entail spotting hundreds of vibrant hot-air balloons. The following are eight seasonal activities in Arizona and New Mexico.

title: In Their Words: Haitian Immigrants in New York Describe Perilous Escape
description: As a young man, Dieu-Nalio Chry fell in love with photography while working in his uncles photo studio in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. But after a powerful earthquake devastated the country in 2010, he turned what had been a freelance pursuit into a profession, going to work for The Associated Press in Haiti.

title: Setting Sail on the Winding Waterways of Californias Delta
description: The wind was a perfect 20 knots, the warm breeze filling our sails, as we angled westward, riding the current down the Sacramento River. We sailed past Sherman Island, slowly cruising through a group of kiteboarders and windsurfers who flew by our hull throwing peace signs. The Montezuma Hills rolled leisurely to the west, dotted with a mass of languorous windmills while tule reeds, permanently slanting eastward, shuddered as a flight of swallows rose in unison.

title: Back on the Bench, the Supreme Court Faces a Blockbuster Term
description: WASHINGTON  A transformed Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday to start a momentous term in which it will consider eliminating the constitutional right to abortion, vastly expanding gun rights and further chipping away at the wall separating church and state.

title: In Search of Fall Colors: A Long Drive on New Hampshire Roads
description: I was born and raised in New Hampshire, and though I have lived many places over the years, I have set nearly every one of my novels in my home state. I give the towns fictional names. But in my head, as I write, I carry pictures of the real places that inspired them and of the seasons in which my stories unfold.

title: In Alaskas Covid Crisis, Doctors Must Decide Who Lives and Who Dies
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: 8 Places to Visit Along Virginias Blue Ridge Parkway
description: With its sweeping vistas and meandering nature, the Blue Ridge Parkway is a scenic delight year-round. But fall is the most celebrated season on the Appalachian Mountain road, when the winding two-lane boulevard is a spectacle with the golden glow of leaves and cool mountain mist. And as we continue to worry about the spread of the coronavirus, a road trip with fresh air and panoramic views lends itself nicely to traveling.

title: Following the Shamrocks on a Canadian Road Trip
description: It looks like the edge of the world out here, my wife, Holly, mused, not disapprovingly. Our picnic blanket was spread out on a high cliff, with green-capped rock stretching alongside us, endless blue ocean in front. It was the first of many leisurely breaks we would take on our slow road trip through Newfoundlands Avalon Peninsula.

title: The Sunday Read: I Had a Chance to Travel Anywhere. Why Did I Pick Spokane?
description: Jon Mooallem, the author of todays Sunday Read, had a bad pandemic.

title: Biden, Supreme Court, Cider: Your Weekend Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: 3,000 Yazidis Are Still Missing. Their Families Know Where Some of Them Are.
description: The voice messages sent by Abbas Husseins teenage son are heartbreaking in their matter-of-factness. The boy, a member of Iraqs Yazidi minority who was kidnapped by Islamic State fighters seven years ago, asks about his mother and wonders why his father has not been in touch.

title: Were All on the Red Carpet Now
description: PARIS  The marquee outside the Thtre du Chtelet, the gilded 19th-century musical theater on the Right Bank, cast a red glow over the fans thronged rows deep in the square outside on Saturday night. A forest of smartphones was held aloft, waving in the night air like a host of alien palm fronds, as various black cars pulled up to disgorge their guests. Penned-in photographers hovered behind a velvet rope while men and women swaggered their way across the red carpet, posing, waving, preening and otherwise camping it up on their way inside.

title: The Yankees (Mostly) Control Their Fate on Seasons Final Day
description: The Yankees will play further into October after Sunday.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 4, 2021
description: Update: Our next Whats Going On in This Picture? live moderated discussion will take place on Oct. 18.

title: The Slugging Rays Found Yet Another Way to Be Different
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Chad Mottola was sure he was done with baseball. He had given 16 years to the game, all to get 25 hits in the majors and a thousand restless nights in the minors. Nagging questions would swirl through his brain at odd hours: How could he change his swing? Would he ever get another call to the majors? Should he quit?

title: A Bag Returns From the Year 2000
description: Fashion Week is back in full force, and theres a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and youll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, well spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.

title: Diapers Are the Latest Pandemic Shortage
description: Anyone recognize him? the police in Winter Haven, Fla., asked on Facebook last month.

title: Breast Implant Companys Sponsorship of Womens Chess Draws Backlash
description: The International Chess Federation, the games governing body, is facing intense criticism from female chess players and others after announcing that a company that makes breast implants would sponsor womens chess events.

title: In Almas Way, a Young Latina Thinks for Herself, Like Her Creator
description: Although Sonia Manzano has won 15 Emmys for television writing and numerous accolades for her decades playing Maria on Sesame Street, she couldnt have been more emphatic  or colorful  when asked if she had ever wanted to develop her own preschool show during all those years.

title: The Week in Business: Facebook Under Pressure and Ozy Media Shuts Down
description: [Watch the Facebook hearing live.]

title: Israel will require a booster shot to be considered fully vaccinated.
description: JERUSALEM  Israel on Sunday introduced new rules for determining coronavirus vaccination status, making a booster shot a requirement for full inoculation and vaccination passports.

title: They Helped Build Modern India but Are Shrinking as a People
description: UDVADA, India  From the porch of his century-old home, Khurshed Dastoor has a front-row seat to a tragedy that he fears may be too late to reverse: the slow extinction of a people who helped build modern India.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. Is this the day I convince you to roast a duck just so you can shred the meat and scatter it over sauted sea scallops, then serve the combination with hollandaise sauce, alongside a peppery watercress salad? Im hoping so! You dont even need to roast a whole duck. A couple of legs will do, cooked low and slow in a kind of confit situation. Shred them when theyre done, make the hollandaise, the salad and then the scallops. Bang, zoom. Thats a Sunday night feast.

title: Want to Change the World? First, Be Still.
description: When I was in college, I met a chain-smoking Franciscan priest who changed my life. He was a chaplain at my university and, like all Franciscans, had taken a vow of poverty. He was smart and compassionate, and I could not doubt his commitment to the marginalized.

title: I Used to Look Up to Elizabeth Holmes
description: When I was a student at Harvard in the early aughts, Mark Zuckerberg and some other classmates dropped out to become the young kings of tech. They were smart, competitive and hard-working  like most people there. But I never could exactly relate. They had a confidence that was hard to describe, a peculiar kind of ambition that seemed to all but entitle them to success. As I got older, I realized the quality I was imagining as special wasnt. They were just men.

title: Protests Are Taking Over the World. Whats Driving Them?
description: September was turbulent: More than 200 Australians arrested during citywide protests and a temporary no-fly zone declared over Melbourne. Rubber bullets and tear gas unleashed by the Thai riot police into an angry crowd. Health care workers assaulted in Canada. Rallies of up to 150,000 people across the Netherlands.

title: Dont Let Amazon Eat the Film Industry
description: In the 1930s and 40s, five major Hollywood studios dominated the film industry and tried to lock up distribution and exhibition channels as well by taking over movie theaters across the country. Courts and regulators saw that allowing studios so much power up and down the film supply chain posed grave threats to the integrity of the industry and to viewer choice.

title: Skateboards, Climate Change and Freedom: Germanys Next-Generation Parliament
description: BERLIN  Emilia Fester is 23 and has yet to finish college. Max Lucks is 24 and calls himself a militant cyclist. Ria Schrder is 29 and has the rainbow flag on her Twitter profile. Muhanad Al-Halak is 31 and came to Germany from Iraq when he was 11.

title: What Happens When the Last Jew Leaves Afghanistan
description: The Last Jew of Afghanistan is gone, and everyone is glad to be rid of him.

title: Democratic Voters See Many Losers in Party Schism, and One Winner: Trump
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  On Election Day in 2018, Cathy Brienza opened her light blue colonial in a New Jersey suburb to dozens of Democratic activists for a get-out-the-vote rally. A freshman congressman, Josh Gottheimer, addressed a crowd filled with voters angered by Donald J. Trumps presidency and hopeful of regaining Democratic control of the House.

description: To the Editor:

description: An explosion outside a mosque in the center of Kabul killed at least three people on Sunday, a Taliban spokesman said, underscoring the challenge of maintaining security for the countrys new rulers after decades of waging war.

title: Fauci says Americans should get vaccinated even if Mercks Covid pill cuts deaths.
description: As the nations death toll climbed above 700,000 in October, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, an adviser on the pandemic to President Biden, emphasized the need for the 70 million Americans who are eligible for a vaccine to get immunized during interviews on Sunday morning talk shows.

title: Review: In Upload, Do Blockchains Dream of Electric Lizards?
description: AMSTERDAM  Im here, thats for sure! the digital facsimile of a father tells his daughter early in Michel van der Aas new opera, Upload.

description: The video looks like it could be b-roll from the 2000 film The Perfect Storm.

title: Major Oil Spill Off California Coast Threatens Wetlands and Wildlife
description: A pipeline failure off the coast of Orange County, Calif., on Saturday caused at least 126,000 gallons of oil to spill into the Pacific Ocean, creating a 13-square-mile slick that continued to grow on Sunday, officials said.

title: Small Plane Crashes Near Milan, Killing All on Board
description: A small plane crashed into an empty building in the outskirts of Milan on Sunday, and its six passengers and two crew members all died, the Italian authorities said.

title: The Delta variant caused a spike in deaths among nursing home residents, a study finds.
description: Although nursing home deaths from Covid-19 remain dramatically down from their peak at the end of last year, a Kaiser Family Foundation analysis shows a significant uptick in August as the Delta variant swept through the country.

title: Progressives Stand Firm on Priorities as Infrastructure Debate Continues
description: After a tumultuous week in Congress, during which deep divisions in the Democratic Party delayed progress on part of President Bidens economic agenda, debate spilled over into the weekend as the party braced for intense negotiations in the weeks ahead.

title: Plane Crash Kills 8 Near Milan
description: The small passenger plane hit an empty building after taking off from Milan.

title: Clint Eastwood Wins $6.1 Million CBD Lawsuit
description: The actor Clint Eastwood and Garrapata, the company that owns the rights to his likeness, were awarded $6.1 million on Friday in a lawsuit they had filed against a Lithuanian company that was accused of using Mr. Eastwoods image and likeness to make it appear as though he was endorsing their products.Last year, Mr. Eastwood filed two lawsuits in federal court in Los Angeles against three CBD manufacturers and marketers whose products were featured in an online article falsely claiming that he endorsed CBD products, as well as 10 online retailers who he accused of manipulating search results through meta tags. (CBD is cannabidiol, a nonintoxicating compound in the cannabis sativa plant.)

title: If Men Needed the Abortions
description: On Thursday, three women of color  sitting members of Congress  testified before the House Committee on Oversight and Reform about abortions they had received, describing, in some cases, the stigma attached to them.

title: Blinken Faces an Awkward Visit to Paris, His Second Home
description: WASHINGTON  The reception could hardly have been warmer when Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken appeared in Frances ornate foreign ministry building on a late June day alongside his French counterpart.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: For two straight days, China sent a record number of planes in its direction, Taiwan said, a display of strength that added muscle to Beijings warnings that it could ultimately use force to take hold of the self-ruled island.

title: The Nosebleed Review: Who Here Hates Their Father?
description: Who here has a father who has died?

title: Stray From a Topic
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Happy Monday, folks! Today we have a collaboration between Christina Iverson (making her ninth New York Times Crossword appearance) and Andrea Carla Michaels (making her 76th!). I enjoyed solving this team effort quite a bit, and as so often happens when a song plays a major role in a puzzle (not a spoiler, its in the clue for 56A!), I ended up with an earworm that I still have not managed to shake loose.

title: Are the Giants and Jets Watchable Yet?
description: This season, weve enlisted two experts  one familiar with the ins and outs of New Yorks football teams, the other a nationally focused football analyst  to answer an essential question as a service to readers: Are these teams good yet?

title: Vietnamese Americans, Once Displaced Themselves, Mobilize to Help Afghans
description: In the middle of the night, Uyen Nguyen trudged through a grassy marshland with her mother and three siblings until they reached the edge of the ocean, where a small, dilapidated fishing boat was beached on the sand. It set off with 31 people packed on it.

title: Jordans King Among Leaders Accused of Amassing Secret Property Empire
description: GAZA CITY  King Abdullah II of Jordan came under heightened scrutiny on Sunday after an alliance of international news organizations reported that he was among several world leaders to use secret offshore accounts to amass overseas properties and hide their wealth.

title: Angelo Codevilla, Whose Writings Anticipated Trumpism, Dies at 78
description: Angelo M. Codevilla, a conservative political theorist whose writings in the 1980s helped define the hawkish wing of the Republican Party and over the last decade both predicted and gave intellectual shape to the populist revolt against the partys establishment that coalesced behind Donald J. Trump, died on Sept. 20 in Tracy, Calif. He was 78.

title: Andrew Wiggins, the Warriors guard who resisted a Covid shot, has gotten one, his coach says.
description: Andrew Wiggins, the Golden State Warriors guard who had resisted getting a Covid-19 vaccine, has received one, the teams coach, Steve Kerr, told reporters on Sunday.

title: Saints Finally Return Home, to a City That Needed Them
description: NEW ORLEANS  The locals streamed down Poydras Street toward the Superdome, walking past tree limbs, over downed poles and through intersections where lights blinked only red. Once they were inside together, they released what the jazz trumpeter Kermit Ruffins last week called the most beautiful sound in the world.

title: What We Learned From Week 4 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Our NFL playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.

title: Crazy, Wild, Tough Year Continues as Yankees Clinch Wild Card
description: The Yankees chased Aaron Judge into the outfield early Sunday night, swarming him in a bouncy, gleeful embrace. Now they will follow Judge to the playoffs.

title: What They Saw in Ozy
description: Theres an irresistible temptation, in this age of scams and hype, to obsess about the man or woman at the center of a companys implosion. Theranoss Elizabeth Holmes was the subject of an HBO documentary, and is now the center of a high-profile trial. And when Ozy Media collapsed on Friday, less than a week after The New York Times reported on a series of misleading statements and actions, all eyes turned to the man at the center of the company, Carlos Watson, an ambitious dreamer who seemed to believe in what he was selling. When he spoke with me over Zoom from a California backyard on Sunday, he conceded nothing.

title: Whistle-Blower Says Facebook Chooses Profits Over Safety
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Tom Brady Returns to Boos in New England but Leaves With a Win
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Tom Bradys much-hyped return to New England to face his former team, the Patriots, and his longtime coach, Bill Belichick, was not the homecoming he envisioned.

title: Review: In Six, All the Tudor Ladies Got Talent
description: Are you an Elsa or an Anna? An Elphaba or a Glinda? Or, for those with more classic tastes, a Vera or a Mame?

title: In Mexico, Nearly 100,000 People Are Missing
description: Nearly 100,000 people have disappeared in Mexico. Their families now search for clues among the dead.

title: Billions Recap, Season 5 Finale: The Axe Falls
description: So this is what it is to lose, says Bobby Axelrod. OK.

title: Damian Lewis Discusses the Future of Billions
description: This article includes spoilers from Sundays Season 5 finale of Billions.

title: China Evergrandes shares are halted as doubts swirl.
description: Shares of China Evergrande were halted on Hong Kongs stock exchange on Monday pending a deal, as doubts swirled over whether the struggling property giant would be able to meet its immense financial obligations.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The U.S. Supreme Court returns to the bench today to start a term in which it will consider eliminating the constitutional right to abortion, vastly expanding gun rights and chipping away at the wall separating church and state.

title: Word of the Day: lugubrious
No Corrections: Oct. 4, 2021
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Quotation of the Day:
description: I am 21st in the tradition. By the time I live my life and I pass my legacy to my son, I doubt that the last of the houses will also be open.

title: Whats on TV This Week: A Rita Moreno Documentary and Ghosts
description: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.

title: Eight Killed as Tensions Around Indias Farm Protests Worsen
description: NEW DELHI  Eight people were killed on Sunday in an incident that protesting farmers said was the fault of the son of a prominent Indian leader, as nearly yearlong demonstrations against a government revamp of the countrys agriculture laws threatened to enter a more volatile phase.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: MONDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Officer Faces Discipline 5 Years After Killing Mentally Ill Woman
description: Police officers attempting to coax a schizophrenic woman out of her bedroom in the Bronx seemed on the verge of succeeding when Sgt. Hugh Barry made a grab for her.

title: The Stock Markets Hot Summer Became a Swoon. Where Does It Go Next?
description: Just four weeks ago, the stock market looked unstoppable. Seven straight months of gains had left the S&P 500 index up 21 percent for the year, corporations enjoyed record profits and economists predicted the fastest growth in decades.

title: Eric Adams Rakes in $7.7 Million, With Help From Wealthy Donors
description: [Follow our live N.Y.C. mayoral debate coverage.]

title: Hungarys Leader Fights Criticism in U.S. via Vast Influence Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Mike Pence turned up in Hungary last month to speak to a conference on conservative social values hosted by the far-right government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban.

title: Teaching About the Native American Fight for Representation, Repatriation and Recognition
description: We have selected six Times articles published in the last year that feature stories of Native Americans who are fighting to ensure representation, repatriation and recognition.

title: The Homeless Shelter Executive Who Earns $1 Million a Year
description: Its Monday. Well look at how executives at nonprofits that run homeless shelters earned large salaries, employed family members and sometimes doubled as for-profit vendors who provided services to their charities. And well look at a school in Queens that counts Japans new prime minister as an alumnus.

title: Indra Nooyi, Ex-C.E.O. of Pepsi, Thinks Big Business Can Do Better
description: Its not about giving away money weve made. Its about how we make money a different way.

title: Should There Be Limits on How Much Time Young People Spend Playing Video Games?
description: China announced this summer that children and teenagers can now play just three hours of video games a week. Young people under 18 are barred from online gaming on school days, and limited to one hour a day on weekend and holiday evenings.

title: Joe Klein Explains How the History of Four Centuries Ago Still Shapes American Culture and Politics
description: Through the spring and summer, Ive been watching the daily maps of Covid-19 cases and vaccinations  the diagonal slash through Appalachia and the South to the Ozarks and Texas, where cases soared; the high vaccination rates in New England  and Ive thought back to ALBIONS SEED: FOUR BRITISH FOLKWAYS IN AMERICA, David Hackett Fischers classic history of British migration to colonial America, which was published in 1989 and explained these phenomena with a clarity that seems even more stunning today. The divide between maskers and anti-maskers, vaxxers and anti-vaxxers is as old as Plymouth Rock. It is deeper than politics; it is cultural.

title: Jocelyn Nicole Johnson Makes Virginias Past Present in My Monticello.
description: MY MONTICELLO FictionBy Jocelyn Nicole Johnson

title: Jean-Georges Vongerichten to Put His Stamp on the Tin Building
description: In his most ambitious project to date, the chef and restaurateur Jean-Georges Vongerichten will fill the Seaport Districts Tin Building with markets, dining counters and restaurants, to open in the spring.

title: A Pillar of the European Order Has Collapsed
description: The drubbing inflicted on Germanys Christian Democratic Union in the countrys recent elections is a sign that, alongside Chancellor Angela Merkels 16-year stint in power, something larger is coming to an end.

title: Acknowledging the Missing and Those Who Try to Find Them
description: Nearly 100,000 people have disappeared in Mexico since 1964, many of them victims of the countrys seemingly endless drug war. The grim phenomenon has left thousands of families searching, sometimes futilely, through deserts and other rural areas in hopes of locating the missing. And it has also resulted in countless unidentified bodies at morgues throughout the country.

title: What America Owes Haitian Asylum Seekers
description: Last month, the Biden administration announced that it had cleared a makeshift tent camp where thousands of Haitians had congregated under a bridge linking Mexico and Del Rio, Texas. They had arrived there desperate to gain admission to the United States, many fleeing persecution in Haiti and seeking the protection of our asylum law. The administrations unsteady response to this crisis has revealed, once again, the broken nature of this countrys asylum system. It also is a grim reminder of the longstanding U.S. tolerance of government corruption and the denial of basic human rights in Haiti.

title: Monica Lewinsky Has Some Things to Say About Cancel Culture
description: Truth and context may seem elusive today, but for Monica Lewinsky they both went out the door in 1998. As the investigation into Bill Clinton unfolded, Lewinsky came under scrutiny as the most infamous intern in Washington, but kept largely silent due to an immunity deal with investigators. In this conversation with Kara Swisher, Lewinsky says she and the other women entangled in the presidents impeachment were all reduced in different ways to serve purposes for other people: for either political points or to make money. She considers the toll of that experience on her own life, and contemplates how it might all have played out differently in the age of online accountability and the #MeToo Twittersphere.

title: The Supreme Court Has Gone Off the Rails
description: The Supreme Court has final authority to make difficult judgment calls articulating the powers of government and the limits and constraints upon them. To merit the public trust, these judgments must not appear simply as assertions of individual value choices by the justices or willy-nilly discard long-established court precedents that profoundly affect peoples lives. Nor should they actively undermine the ability of governments to advance public purposes as established by a fair democratic process.

title: Facebook Is Weaker Than We Knew
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: N.Y.C. Schools Vaccine Mandate Is in Place. 96% of Teachers Got a Shot.
description: New Yorks requirement that virtually everyone who works in the citys public schools be vaccinated against the coronavirus compelled thousands of Department of Education employees to get at least one dose of a vaccine in the past week, leading to extremely high vaccination rates among educators, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday.

title: Conservatives, Often Wary of Foreign Law, Look Abroad in Abortion Case
description: WASHINGTON  Not so long ago, conservatives found it maddening when U.S. judges cited foreign law in their decisions interpreting the Constitution.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Seek F.D.A. Authorization for Booster Shot
description: WASHINGTON  Johnson & Johnson is planning to ask federal regulators early this week to authorize a booster shot of its coronavirus vaccine, according to officials familiar with the companys plans. The firm is the last of the three federally authorized vaccine providers to call for extra injections, amid mounting evidence that at least the elderly and other high-risk groups need more protection.

title: Whats a Little Disagreement Among Factions?
description: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I have a new grand theory of politics: The Stupid Party is whichever party happens to be in power. Fair?

title: U.S. Signals No Thaw in Trade Relations With China
description: WASHINGTON  The Biden administration offered its strongest signal yet that the United States combative economic approach toward China would continue, with senior administration officials saying that President Biden would not immediately lift tariffs on Chinese goods and that he would hold Beijing accountable for trade commitments agreed to during the Trump administration.

title: Shopping for Decorative Boxes
description: The best decorative boxes are both storage containers and functional art: They corral little things like jewelry and office supplies, but theyre also interesting on their own.

title: They Didnt Want to Sing Spirituals, but They Did  and Changed American Music
description: NASHVILLE  In an account of her years as assistant director of the Fisk Jubilee Singers, Ella Sheppard, a gifted musician who had been enslaved as a child, recalled one of the student ensembles earliest excursions outside Nashville, only a handful of years after the Civil War. The singers were all students at Fisk University, a school for emancipated former slaves. They were stranded at a rural train station with Ms. Sheppard and their director, a white abolitionist named George White, when an angry mob arrived. In the face of the white mens fury, the students began to sing.

title: In New Orleans, a Designer With a Daring, Completist Vision
description: The artist and designer Bradley L. Bowers does not have much regard for categorical distinctions. He creates wallpaper, jewelry, furniture, ceramics, lighting and textiles, as well as interiors and installation work. I like to work with the material or medium that makes the most sense for the project at hand, said Bowers, speaking from his New Orleans studio this past summer. The thing that makes jewelry different from sculpture is its made out of silver, and its smaller. The only thing that really distinguishes them is the title. Its all creative energy.

title: The Beginning of the Snowball: Supply-Chain Snarls Delay Books
description: Days after the release of Rebecca Donners book, All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days, its hardcover edition sold out on Amazon, then at the online retailer Bookshop.org and at Powells Books. When it made its debut on the New York Times best-seller list, the countrys largest book retailer didnt have any copies.

title: The Textile Artist Employing Centuries-Old Practices and Pop Culture Imagery
description: As a queer undergrad studying fiber arts and weaving at the University of North Texas, the artist Sarah Zapata was wary of color. Using it made me really nervous, which is so hilarious now, she says, smiling through neon orange tresses. Theres so much power that exists within color. Theres so much joy and beauty, as well as darkness.

title: Its Like Kismet: How a Long-Empty Building Found the Perfect Tenant
description: When New York City locked down in March 2020, the meal delivery organization Gods Love We Deliver received 3,500 calls from people seeking help in a single weekend. By the end of June that year, the number of daily meals it was producing had increased by 2,500.

title: A Furniture Maker Working to Expand the Definition of British Design
description: The first thing that strikes you about Mac Collinss original ash-wood Iklwa chair is the color. A searing ultramarine, it references the celestial blue of Afrofuturism and, with its throne-like shape and spear-modeled armrests (an iklwa is a short stabbing spear innovated by the Zulu nation in the 19th century), is intended to invoke authority and entitlement. A more personal aspect is at play as well: The blue is the same shade as the tailored suit that Collinss grandfather Clifton wore when he immigrated to England from Jamaica in 1955 as part of what is known in the UK as the Windrush Generation.

title: The Artist Who Dreamed Up a Kaleidoscopic Basketball Court for Londons Canary Wharf
description: Having grown up in a vibrant multicultural community of immigrants in London, Yinka Ilori was acutely aware of color from a young age. I would go to these parties and see a cluster of my moms friends wearing pink, and another cluster of women wearing purple, and the men wearing green, recalls the 34-year-old Nigerian-British artist and designer, describing how groups of friends would purchase the same fabric and orchestrate matching outfits for celebrations. Those early memories of color blocking, as he calls it, eventually found vivid expression in Iloris work: The artist uses kaleidoscopic hues and energetic shapes in an eclectic range of projects, from architecture and furniture to public sculpture and urban interventions. Whether hes creating carnivalesque cultural and social spaces (like his summer installation in the courtyard of Londons historic Somerset House) or reimagining forgotten elements of the cityscape (swathing a dreary underpass in rainbow tones), he seeks to spark euphoria and foster connection via an aesthetic that marries the sensory richness of his Nigerian heritage with pristine yet provocative designs.

title: A Floral Designer Who Heightens the Drama of Nature
description: I met the floral designer Doan Ly at her studio, an industrial loft near the Brooklyn Navy Yard that she shares with the interior plant designer Lisa Muoz. Stems littered the cement floor, and one of Lys assistants, Myke Marinkovich, was tidying up the work space with cheery efficiency. Ly showed me some garden roses, plucking them out of a water bucket and pinching their petals delicately between her fingers as she pointed out the complex, open structure that differentiates them from more tightly petaled varieties. I love romantic flowers, she said. I love having the chance to be around a lush, really overgrown, gushy world.

title: A Dispatch From an Endangered Birds Garden of Eden
description: By the end of 2019, I was ready for a change of scenery. Working as a natural history photographer, Id spent the previous two years tracking snow leopards in the Himalayas. Then, one snowy afternoon, I received a brief call from Dr. Rohit Naniwadekar, a bird biologist with the Nature Conservation Foundation. He asked me to get to a small volcanic island in the northern Andaman Sea as quickly as I possibly could.

title: An Artist Couple Who Live Among the Furniture They Create Together
description: For the artists Chris Johanson and Johanna Jackson, the border between art and design is as blurred as that between work and life. The couple, based in Portland, Ore., and Los Angeles, have been married for 18 years and have worked under the same roof, more or less, since first striking up a friendship in a San Francisco bookstore in the 90s. And though the bulk of their oeuvres are distinct  Johanson is considered a linchpin of the Mission School, the post-punk movement that borrowed from both graffiti and folk art, for his colorful semi-figurative paintings, while Jackson is known for exploring the poetic and surrealist potential of handmade household objects, as with a U-shaped porcelain candelabra or a sculpture that incorporates sweaters she hand-knit  the couple have also been quietly collaborating for a decade on collage-like salvaged-wood furniture and functional structures, which populate their own home and studios. This fall, some of these pieces will make their way into his-and-hers solo shows in New York (Johansons opens in October at Mitchell-Innes & Nash, Jacksons in November at Tennis Elbow at The Journal Gallery), each offering an immersive view of the artists range and overlap during this recent housebound era.

title: A Textile Designer Who Draws on Art History and Neuroscience
description: As a child, Ellen Van Dusen became fixated on the kinetic colors in the artist Ellsworth Kellys paintings, which shed come upon during her frequent museum visits in Washington, D.C., where she grew up. She was puzzled by Kellys abstract minimalist works, several of which comprise flat, solid stretches of a single shade; I was like, Its just a green canvas; whats wrong with my brain? says the 35-year-old owner of the textiles and home-accessories brand Dusen Dusen. Such questions stuck with her when she was an undergraduate at Tufts, where she majored in a multidisciplinary mix of art history, neuroscience and visual anthropology. I studied the visual process from different angles, she says. Neuroscience is where I focused on vision: how things come through the eye, how theyre processed through the brain and what evolutionarily draws the eye. But she kept coming back to color.

title: How a Design Devotee Turned Her Passion Into a Thriving Business
description: Maggie Holladay was a collector of design objects with a serious tchotchke-hoarding habit  accumulating marble ashtrays and espresso demitasses by the dozen, to cite just two examples  when her then boyfriend staged an intervention. His advice was to stop amassing and start selling. Holladay agreed, and before long shed graduated from knickknacks to more substantial pieces. I started out with little marketplace finds, but then found one amazing item and made a huge profit off it, she says; it was a modular channel boucl sofa she sold to the model Elsa Hosk, who bought it prior to an Architectural Digest shoot featuring her SoHo apartment. That such a transaction was eminently iterative was not lost on her: I repeated this process of saving up to buy one really great item and reselling it, she says.

title: The Rug Designer Inspired by the Colors and Craft Traditions of India
description: Indias grandest Jantar Mantar, a grouping of oddly yet precisely shaped stone and marble structures that together form an astronomical observatory, is in Jaipur, and is especially known for its 74-foot-tall sundial. For Arati Rao, the founder of the Brooklyn-based rug and textiles company Tantuvi, the site is a wonder  partly because though it looks like a contemporary art installation, it was actually built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II in the early 18th century. It always just blows my mind, she says. The curves, the lines  it feels so modern and fresh. Its a place that Rao, 39, goes on almost every trip she makes to India (pre-pandemic, she would typically visit once or twice a year) and that frequently sparks inspiration for her creations, which have abstract and geometric properties of their own.

title: In New York, a Magazine Editor Whos Also a Furniture Maker
description: When the designer and writer Emmanuel Olunkwa lived with roommates, he would lie on the couch and consider the apartment, all the things in it and how they could be different. I would think, What if that could go there? Is that big enough? Does that make sense? Do I want   At this point in reciting his list of self-prompts, the 27-year-old broke out into a crash of laughter. Ive always gotten into trouble for being overly analytic, hed tell me, later in our conversation. Nonetheless, its a quality that drives him. Olunkwa, whose practice includes furniture design, architecture, editing, writing and producing the occasional radio show, is ceaselessly probing and interrogating the world around him  and the world he wants to create.

title: An In-Demand Maker of Poetic, Off-Kilter Furniture
description: Minjae Kims studio in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is littered with blocks of wood being shaped into something more, but only two pieces in the space appear to be finished: a lamp in one corner resembling a giant oyster and pearl on a pedestal, a self-illuminating sculpture poised somewhere between art and design; and, on the wall above, a painting by his mother, MyoungAe Lee. If his work space leaves an inchoate impression on this August afternoon, its likely because the 32-year-old designer hasnt had time to fully inhabit it, having quit his job at the prestigious design firm Studio Giancarlo Valle only a few weeks earlier in order to become a furniture designer full-time. His decision to venture out on his own was the culmination of a heady year and a half, during which Kim established himself as one of the most sought-after furniture makers in the contemporary design space, using primarily wood and fiberglass to fashion chairs, tables, lamps and cabinets possessed of a poetic, off-kilter presence. Its very wild, he says of his recent dizzying ascent. It gives me some anxiety, too, because I feel like it could go away so easily.

title: 12 Talents Shaping the Design World
description: Whether they make furniture, housewares, textiles or floral arrangements, these creative forces bring a singular perspective and devotion to their work.

title: London Police Announce Independent Review Amid Trust Crisis
description: LONDON  Londons Metropolitan Police on Monday announced an independent review into its culture and standards following damaging revelations about police behavior during the sentencing hearing last week for the police officer who killed a 33-year-old woman as she was walking home at night.

title: How Much Do You Know About Syria?
description: Can you find Syria on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with a population of 17 million people?

title: Nobel Prize Awarded for Research About Temperature and Touch
description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded jointly on Monday to David Julius and Ardem Patapoutian, two scientists who independently discovered key mechanisms of how people sense heat, cold, touch and their own bodily movements.

title: Vaccination rates rise among teachers and other employees as a mandate takes effect in N.Y.C.s schools.
description: New Yorks requirement that virtually everyone who works in the citys public schools be vaccinated against the coronavirus compelled thousands of Department of Education employees to get at least one dose of a vaccine in the past week, leading to extremely high vaccination rates among educators, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday.

title: Whats Behind the Ivermectin Frenzy?
description: Ivermectin is a drug that emerged in the 1970s, used mainly for deworming horses and other animals.

title: Battling Delta, New Zealand Abandons Its Zero-Covid Ambitions
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  For a year and a half, New Zealand has pursued a strategy of Covid zero, closing its borders and quickly enforcing lockdowns to keep the coronavirus in check, a policy it maintained even as other Asia-Pacific countries transitioned to coexisting with the viral threat.

title: Covid, in Retreat
description: Covid-19 is once again in retreat.

title: New Zealand abandons its goal of eliminating the coronavirus.
description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand acknowledged an end on Monday to the countrys strategy of eliminating the coronavirus, announcing that restrictions would be gradually lifted in Auckland, the countrys largest city.

title: How Old Is the Maltese, Really?
description: The tiny Maltese, the American Kennel Club tells us, has been sitting in the lap of luxury since the Bible was a work in progress.

title: Oil prices hit a seven-year high as OPEC and its allies stick with a modest increase.
description: Oil prices hit their highest levels since 2014 as officials from OPEC, Russia and other oil producers decided on Monday to stick with their previous agreement to only gradually add oil to the market. The announcement came despite rising demand for energy as businesses around the world resumed operations.

title: Profit Over Safety
description: The hits keep coming for Facebook. Last night, in an interview on 60 Minutes, a former Facebook product manager described how she had leaked internal documents to The Wall Street Journal. The newspaper had published a series of eye-opening articles dubbed The Facebook Files, detailing what the social media giant knew about the harms its platform was causing.

title: Carlisle Floyd: Artists Share Memories of a Composer
description: The career of the American composer Carlisle Floyd, who died on Thursday at 95, spanned nearly 70 years and the heydays of a host of musical styles. But through them all, Floyd stayed stubbornly true to himself and his vision: creating operas with clear, strong narratives  often about intolerance and social outcasts  and scores grounded in tonality.

title: Supply-chain snarls reach the book publishing industry.
description: The churning disruption in the global supply chain has now reached the world of books, just as the holiday season  a crucial time for publishers and bookstores  approaches.

title: How Californians View Abortion
description: The hundreds of womens marches staged across the country over the weekend had a clear rallying cry: Dont let America go the way of Texas.

title: Party Shirt Is Here to Bust That Viral Life Hack
description: Names: Xavier Di Petta and Nick Iavarone

title: A New Pal Joey Is Broadway Bound
description: Pal Joey is coming back to Broadway.

title: With Their Season on the Line, the Yankees Go to Their Go-to Guy
National Endowment for the Humanities Awards Covid Relief Grants
description: The New York Public Library, the USS Constitution Museum in Boston and the Thomas Jefferson Foundation in Charlottesville, Va., are among more than 300 beneficiaries of new Covid relief grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities that are being announced on Monday.

title: Making Very Short Memories at Givenchy and Lanvin
description: PARIS  In one of the more unexpected runway trends of the moment, the middle-aged model is hot. (Also the edging toward middle-age-in-model-terms model.)

title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: This house and the neighboring unit that shares a wall with it were designed by Kevin Daly, an architect whose work includes educational and residential buildings around Los Angeles. Mr. Dalys goal was to reimagine the townhouse, focusing on access to the outdoors and bringing an abundance of natural light into every room.

title: What You Get for $2.2 Million in California
description: A contemporary house in Santa Monica, a Mediterranean-style home in Piedmont and a three-bedroom retreat in a gated community in Dana Point.

title: Military Personnel in U.K. Begin Driving Fuel Trucks to Stem Shortage
description: Military personnel in Britain began driving fuel tankers on Monday as the government stepped up efforts to tackle a shortage of truck drivers that has closed some gas stations, caused panic buying and long lines at others, and threatened wider disruption in the run-up to Christmas.

title: Todd Akin, Whose Senate Bid Collapsed After a Rape Remark, Dies at 74
description: Todd Akin, a six-term Republican representative from Missouri who gave up a safe House seat to run for the Senate in 2012, only to see his campaign collapse in a hail of recriminations after a remark about legitimate rape, died on Sunday at his home in Wildwood, Mo., a St. Louis suburb. He was 74.

title: Did Death Cheat Stephen Hawking of a Nobel Prize?
description: Did death cheat Stephen Hawking of a Nobel Prize?

title: Stocks drop again as Big Tech tumbles.
description: Stocks on Wall Street dipped on Monday, with the S&P 500, the benchmark U.S. index, losing 1.3 percent and the Nasdaq composite dropping 2.1 percent.

title: After Ozys Carlos Watson Talks of a Comeback, a Key Investor Objects
description: Hours after Carlos Watson, the chief executive of Ozy Media, appeared on morning news programs to say he would revive his company, which announced on Friday that it had shut down, a prominent early investor in Ozy demanded that he spend its remaining cash to pay its employees.

title: The Devastating Ways Depression and Anxiety Impact the Body
description: Its no surprise that when a person gets a diagnosis of heart disease, cancer or some other life-limiting or life-threatening physical ailment, they become anxious or depressed. But the reverse can also be true: Undue anxiety or depression can foster the development of a serious physical disease, and even impede the ability to withstand or recover from one. The potential consequences are particularly timely, as the ongoing stress and disruptions of the pandemic continue to take a toll on mental health.

title: Back in the Kitchen
description: Good morning. I was on the road for a few days, and not cooking at all. The food was fine while traveling  wings and tots, a pepperoni and Parmesan croissant, a decent cheese steak, a better-than-decent Italian sub and a remarkable beet smoothie from a juice bar in Lorain, Ohio, that I drank in front of Toni Morrisons childhood home. But I missed my kitchen, missed making food for the family, missed sitting at our table together with the dog asleep at my feet.

title: Losing Your Hair? You Might Blame the Great Stem Cell Escape.
description: Every person, every mouse, every dog, has one unmistakable sign of aging: hair loss. But why does that happen?

title: A Pacemaker for the Brain: No Treatment Helped Her Depression  Until This
description: Driving home from work in Northern California five years ago, a young woman was so overwhelmed with depression that all she could think about was ending her life.

title: Englands international Covid travel rules have been simplified.
description: LONDON  Streamlined coronavirus restrictions on international travel in and out of England came into effect on Monday, including an easing of testing and quarantine requirements for fully vaccinated arrivals.

title: Matthew Rhys Hits the Seas
description: Matthew Rhys never planned on buying an old wooden boat that would take four years, tens of thousands of dollars and quite a bit of his own manual labor to restore. But one night he was drinking whiskey and clicking through eBay, and, well, one thing led to another.

title: Global trade is accelerating, but poorer countries need vaccines to keep up, the W.T.O. says.
description: Global trade recovered from its pandemic lows faster than anticipated in the first half of 2021 and is set to grow more quickly than expected next year, lifting global growth forecasts, the World Trade Organization said Monday.

title: How (and Why) to Kill a Lanternfly
description: States are calling on citizens to engage in a effort to stomp out the invasive lanternfly. Here's how.

title: Why the Talibans Repression of Women May Be More Tactical Than Ideological
description: Why are the Taliban stripping away so many of Afghan womens hard-won freedoms?

title: Former Manchester United Player Condemns Racist Fan Song
description: Park Ji-Sung, a fan-favorite former player for Manchester United, asked the soccer clubs fans on Sunday to stop singing a song in his honor that includes the racist stereotype that Koreans eat dog meat.

title: Swedish Artist Known for Muhammad Caricature Dies in Car Crash
description: Lars Vilks, an artist and free speech activist whose cartoon depiction of the Prophet Muhammad on the body of a dog in 2007 made him the target of numerous assassination attempts, was killed in a car crash in Sweden on Sunday, the police said.

title: Andrew Yang Says He Left Democratic Party to Become Independent
description: Andrew Yang, the former long-shot presidential candidate and onetime technology entrepreneur, announced on Monday that he had left the Democratic Party and become an independent.

title: Gone in Minutes, Out for Hours: Outage Shakes Facebook
description: [Watch the Facebook hearing live.]

title: Britains Christmas Lament: Meat Shortages and Delivery Delays
description: BUNGAY, England  To understand the deep sense of anxiety Britons feel about the supply shortages currently afflicting the nation  and threatening disruptions to the Christmas dinner table  one need only travel to Simon Watchorns pig farm, about two hours northeast of London.

title: Like Captain Kirk, William Shatner Will Travel to Space (Almost)
description: Hes boldly going where Jeff Bezos has gone before.

title: Swing Today: Our Dance Is Modern Because Were Alive Right Now
description: Choices picked out of a hat: Its a gambit of magicians and improv comedians, a way of showing an audience that chance is at work and performers are creating on the fly.

title: Biden Accuses Republicans of Being Reckless Over Debt Limit Increase
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden excoriated Republicans on Monday for blocking his partys efforts to raise the debt ceiling weeks before a projected government default, calling their tactics reckless and disgraceful and warning they risked causing a self-inflicted wound that takes our economy over a cliff.

title: U.S. Virgin Islands Coronavirus Map and Case Count
description: See the latest charts and maps of coronavirus cases, deaths, hospitalizations and vaccinations in U.S. Virgin Islands.

title: Northern Mariana Islands Coronavirus Map and Case Count
description: See the latest charts and maps of coronavirus cases, deaths, hospitalizations and vaccinations in Northern Mariana Islands.

title: Guam Coronavirus Map and Case Count
description: See the latest charts and maps of coronavirus cases, deaths, hospitalizations and vaccinations in Guam.

title: Europes drug regulator said a booster shot of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine could be given to healthy adults.
description: The European Medicines Agency, the European Unions main drug regulator, said on Monday that a booster shot of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine could be given to healthy adults at least six months after the second dose.

title: Elizabeth Warren Calls for an Insider Trading Inquiry at the Fed
description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, called on Monday for an investigation into whether top Federal Reserve officials engaged in insider trading in 2020, when some bought and sold securities that could have benefited from central bank policy moves.

title: Biden and the Democratic Standoff Over Spending Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: ATP Will Investigate Domestic Abuse Allegations Against Alexander Zverev
description: After months of delay and complaints from players and tennis officials, the mens professional tennis tour announced Monday that it would investigate Alexander Zverev after accusations of domestic abuse made by a former girlfriend.

title: How the Many Saints of Newark Stars Remade Key Sopranos Roles
description: From its debut in 1999 to its blackout finale in 2007, The Sopranos set a seemingly unsurpassable benchmark for acting. The cast members of that HBO crime drama, leading players and supporting performers alike, became synonymous with the menacing mobsters and manipulative family members they portrayed. When it was all over, you couldnt imagine anyone else playing those roles.

title: Facebook urges court to dismiss latest F.T.C. antitrust suit.
description: [Watch the Facebook hearing live.]

title: Oyster Shoreline at Greater New York Has a Pearl of a Message
description: To get to Newtown Creek, a severely polluted New York City waterway and Superfund site once teeming with oyster beds, the Mohawk artist Alan Michelson wended his way past the detritus of industrial Queens  the garbage haulers, the taco truck parking lots, the Mount Everests of scrap metal and building debris being clawed by construction cranes.

title: An Acclaimed Playwright on Masks and the Return to the Stage
description: In the theater, we smile. We smile because the show must go on. We smile, to quote Nat King Cole, even when our hearts are breaking. Unless we are performers in a tragedy, we put on some glitter and we sail out into the night, toward the theater district. Even writers, the least performative of the lot, smile. I didnt want to be an opaque, judging playwright at auditions; I wanted to mirror the actors joy, or sadness, and partake of the strange communion between performers and their first audience. I never expected that one day, during a pandemic, we would all come to the theater masked.

title: With 4 Color Books, Bryant Terry Looks to Color Outside the Lines
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: On Very Serious People, Climate and Children
description: Do you remember the days of the Simpson-Bowles debt-reduction plan?

title: Our 3rd Annual STEM Writing Contest
description: How do daddy longlegs grow such strange legs? Can genetically engineered bacteria help us detect buried land mines? Why does snow sometimes turn red? Can Saturns rings help to reveal whats happening in the planets core?

title: Major Labels Wraps Popular Music  All of It  in a Warm Embrace
description: Its rare for a book of poetry in America to get a negative review. Its always been so. The field is so small, the stakes so apparently low, that pricking any but the most inflated reputation can seem, as the phrase goes, like breaking a butterfly on a wheel.

title: Hollywood Crew Union Votes to Authorize Strike Against Studios
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood moved closer to a production shutdown on Monday after one of the film and television industrys lower-profile unions said that members had overwhelmingly voted to authorize a strike.

title: Fords sales fell 27 percent in the third quarter because of chip shortages.
description: Ford Motor said Monday that its sales of new vehicles in the United States fell about 27 percent in the three months that ended in September from the same period a year earlier. The drop was in line with the rest of the auto industry, which has been hampered by a global shortage of computer chips.

title: These Online Publications Are Not Free  and Readers Dont Mind
description: You had to pay to get in.

title: Venice, Overwhelmed by Tourists, Tries Tracking Them
description: VENICE  As the pandemic chased away visitors, some Venetians allowed themselves to dream of a different city  one that belonged as much to them as to the tourists who crowd them out of their stone piazzas, cobblestone alleyways and even their apartments.

title: With Bidens Agenda in the Balance, Lobbying Kicks Into High Gear
description: WASHINGTON  As centrist Democrats in Congress have worked to block or strip out major provisions of President Bidens $3.5 trillion social safety net and climate plan, a string of online ads has popped up in their states and districts, lavishing praise on them.

title: Kamla Bhasin, a First-Wave South Asian Feminist, Dies at 75
description: NEW DELHI  Kamla Bhasin, an activist, poet and writer who was an early leader of the womens movement in India, died here on Sept. 25. She was 75.

title: Remembering Pvt. Danny Chen, at a Precarious Moment for Chinatown
description: Before he was an Army private, before the events of his tragic death sparked a national reckoning over military hazing and rallied his neighbors to demand justice, before his name was on the street sign at the corner of Canal and Elizabeth Streets and his life had inspired an opera, Danny Chen was just a teenager from Chinatown.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The Biden administration offered its strongest signal yet that the U.S. would maintain the combative economic approach toward China that was adopted under former President Trump, using trade barriers and other punitive measures.

title: Zombie Urchins Are Destroying Kelp Forests. Cant We Just Eat Them?
description: ALBION, Calif.  A decade ago, when Gary Trumper used to dive for sea urchins, the docks here were packed with commercial fishing vessels. Mr. Trumper and his diving partner, Byron Koehler, would steer through masses of tangled kelp and return after a few hours of work with what Mr. Koehler described as enough red urchin to sink their 26-foot boat.

title: New Yorks largest health care provider fires 1,400 unvaccinated employees.
description: Northwell Health, New York States largest health care provider, announced on Monday that 1,400 employees  less than 2 percent of its staff  refused to get vaccinated against the coronavirus and had to leave their jobs.

title: The Feds Great Dissenter
description: A dissent can seem cranky. Look, you lost. Dont waste everyones time relitigating the case.

title: Pro Tennis Finds New Cities to Play In, but Will It Return?
description: SAN DIEGO  The small tennis stadium was packed and in full roar as Daniel Vallverd watched Casper Ruud and Grigor Dimitrov trade blows and breaks of serve on Saturday.

title: The Man Who Put French Soccer at Risk Says Its Not His Fault
description: Sitting alone on a long table inside a committee room deep inside Frances national assembly, the Spanish businessman tried to explain why things had gone wrong, so very wrong.

title: Hilliards Chocolates Enters the Pumpkin Spice Chat
description: With fall comes pumpkin spice. But before you say Oh no! consider the ever so subtle caramels from Hilliards Chocolates, a company that is almost 100 years old and has stores in Norwell, North Easton and Mansfield, Mass. Each chewy bite coated in dark chocolate with seasonal orange tracing delivers a whiff of warming pumpkin spice.

title: Energy Prices Spike as Producers Worry Over Pandemic and Climate
description: HOUSTON  Americans are spending a dollar more for a gallon of gasoline than they were a year ago. Natural gas prices have shot up more than 150 percent over the same time, threatening to raise prices of food, chemicals, plastic goods and heat this winter.

title: A Book for Your Johnny Appleseed
description: How apples grow and reproduce, and the history, evolution and symbolism of the fruit are discussed in a compelling introduction in Odd Apples, a new book of apple photographs. The sometimes surprising photos display the colorful varieties, many with red or pink flesh. Youll discover the fancifully striped Red St. Lawrence from Maine, the sleek Arkansas Black, the ruby Hidden Rose from Oregon, the pearly Yellow Transparent from Russia and several tortured knobbed russets from Sussex, England. At the end theres a paragraph devoted to each one. The book, representing three years work, comes in a large format that includes a print of the Hidden Rose apple; a smaller, less expensive version of the book does not.

title: New Condiments to Add Kick to Dinner
description: Maya Kaimal, whose company produces myriad sauces, condiments and other ingredients for Indian cooking, has just introduced hot sauces. Not that her marinades, simmer sauces and ketchup lacked that kick, but these newcomers, inspired by her familys recipes from Kerala, are designed to deliver compelling heat when drizzled on vegetables, eggs, cheese and seafood. The green combines forceful serrano chiles and ginger with a sweet note from coconut cream; the reds Kashmiri chiles and red jalapeos are tempered by tamarinds citric tartness. They come in convenient squeeze bottles.

title: Jos Andrs Expands His Mail Order Offerings
description: Jos Andrs, the Spanish chef and restaurateur known for feeding those in need through his organization, World Central Kitchen, is ready to ship some of his specialties to food-lovers able to pay a substantial price. While his paella kits were available in the New York area through his Mercado Little Spain in Hudson Yards, Goldbelly has given him the ability to go wider with a collection of dinners, along with the makings of a tapas party. Some cooking and other prep work is required; the ingredients are shipped frozen or chilled. Theres paella with red shrimp ($179, serving three), Ibrico pork steak with aioli and pan con tomate ($199, serving four), Wagyu rib-eye steak with a salad ($329, serving six) and tapas of charcuterie, cheese, croquettes and pan con tomate ($179, serving four to six). Cheesecake meets crme brle in the burnt Basque cheesecake for $109 to serve 12. The prices include shipping.

title: Whimsical Pumpkins With a Twist
description: For fall, Simon Pearce, the Vermont company known for tableware and decorative accessories, has become pumpkin central. The company has introduced a new line of beautiful art-glass pumpkins, crystal clear with intricate twisted stems, for your elegant harvest or Thanksgiving table. Theyre a more elaborate version of the plain large glass pumpkin the company has made in the past (which is still available, $230). The new Pumpkins With a Twist come in three sizes: small (about four inches, $125), medium (about six inches, $175) and large (about nine inches, $240). There are also glazed pottery pumpkins in sunset, a honey tone, and candent gray, medium ($165) and large ($230), all with no practical purpose beyond admiration.

title: The Banana as Muse
description: Homage to the banana plays out at a display at Fort Makers, a design studio and gallery run by artists in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. It was inspired by news of a deadly pathogen infecting banana farms. The show is meant to celebrate the threatened fruit. Historical pieces and newly commissioned works share the gallery. Theres a machine-tufted rug called War Rug, with references to banana republics, by Johannah Herr; Rebecca Morgans ironic Banana Smile; and a banana scarf by Lilian Martinez. The works are for sale, $250 to $80,000. The exhibition will be up through Nov. 28 from noon to 6 p.m. on Wednesdays and Sundays, and from noon to 7 p.m. Thursdays through Saturdays.

title: Lovely Warren, Troubled Rochester Mayor, to Resign in Plea Deal
description: Lovely Warren, the embattled Democratic mayor of Rochester, N.Y., agreed to resign on Monday as part of a plea deal on several state criminal charges, capping a swift and staggering fall for a politician once considered a rising star in the state Democratic Party.

title: Thailands Quarantine-Island Experiment Is Showing (Modest) Results
description: PHUKET, Thailand  Three months ago, with great fanfare, Thailand began a campaign to start reviving its crucial tourism industry by letting visitors who follow strict Covid-19 protocols roam freely on the resort island of Phuket.

title: A safety agency finds no cause to investigate Tesla battery safety.
description: The federal governments top auto-safety regulator has declined to open a formal investigation into the fire risk in Tesla vehicles with fully charged batteries after finding no relevant incidents in the United States in the last two years.

title: Gunfire on Amtrak Train: D.E.A. Agent Killed, 2nd Agent Is Critically Wounded
description: A federal drug enforcement agent was killed and another was critically injured in a chaotic scene of gunfire aboard a crowded Amtrak train while it was stopped at a station in Tucson, Ariz., on Monday morning, the citys police chief said.

title: Dolce & Gabbana Just Set a $6 Million Record for Fashion NFTs
description: The digital worlds cancellation of Dolce & Gabbana after a series of offensive statements about race, sexuality and size, which reached its apogee in 2018 when the fashion house released a video in China featuring a Chinese model clumsily eating spaghetti with chopsticks, appears to have reached a multimillion-dollar end.

title: Should You Care About Unvaccinated N.B.A. Players?
description: Last week, Kyrie Irving, the star guard for the Brooklyn Nets, missed the teams media day at the Barclays Center. There was much speculation that Irving actually could not legally enter the building because of New York Citys proof-of-vaccination requirements, which, in turn, could preclude him from playing any games in cities with similar mandates. Irving, instead, chose to talk to reporters by video conference. When asked if he planned to play home games this season, Irving said, Please respect my privacy regarding home games, whats happening with my vaccination.

title: Biden Officials End Ban on Abortion Referrals at Federally Funded Clinics
description: WASHINGTON  The Biden administration on Monday reversed a contentious policy set under President Donald J. Trump that barred organizations that provide abortion referrals from receiving federal family planning money.

title: Mets Part Ways With Manager After Two Extremely Trying Years
description: After two losing seasons under Manager Luis Rojas, the Mets want a change. The team announced on Monday that it had declined the option for the 2022 season on Rojass contract, ending his tenure. The team was 103-119 under his watch.

title: Guggenheim Gets New Chairman, and Second Ever Black Female Trustee
description: At a time when the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is working to address charges from within its own ranks that it is an inequitable work environment that enables racism, the museum on Monday appointed a new chairman, the billionaire collector J. Tomilson Hill, and elected its second ever Black female trustee, the poet, playwright and essayist Claudia Rankine.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Alaska is currently home to the nations worst Covid-19 outbreak, and doctors there are  facing the nightmare scenario of rationing care.

title: Facebook, Nobel Prizes, Captain Kirk: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: California Oil Spill Closes Beaches and Renews Call for Drilling Ban
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif.  The most prominent visible sign on Monday of the major offshore oil spill that threatened some of Southern Californias most popular beaches was a single strip of yellow caution tape blocking the water.

title: One Justice Missing and Only One Masked, the Supreme Court Returns
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court returned to its majestic mahogany bench on Monday after a pandemic-induced absence of more than 18 months, starting a new term that will include major cases on abortion and gun rights.

title: Pfizer vaccine provides 90 percent protection against hospitalization for six months, study finds.
description: The Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine is 90 percent effective at preventing hospitalization for up to six months, with no signs of waning during that time period, according to a large new U.S. study conducted by researchers at Pfizer and Kaiser Permanente.

title: Hochul Locks Up Key Support as Letitia James Begins Statewide Tour
description: The chairman of the New York State Democratic Party on Monday endorsed Gov. Kathy Hochul in next years primary race, arguing that a fierce multicandidate free-for-all could be damaging to the party  even as several potential contenders take increasingly serious steps toward runs of their own.

title: Users turn to Twitter after Facebook outage. Jokes and venting ensue.
description: [Watch the Facebook hearing live.]

title: How Do You Win a Do-or-Die Game in Fenway? These Guys Know.
description: When asked how the Yankees could get past the Boston Red Sox in a wild-card game that could extend or end a season that has had countless ups and downs, Bucky Dent had some tongue-in-cheek advice: Use Mickey Riverss bat.

title: Missouri Executes Death Row Prisoner Despite Pleas From Pope and Others
description: A Missouri man convicted of beating three people to death during a 1994 convenience store robbery was executed on Tuesday night despite calls for clemency from Pope Francis and other supporters who said the mans intellectual disabilities made the execution unconstitutional.

title: Rome Mayor Loses Re-election Bid, a Defeat for Five Star Movement
description: ROME  Voters on Monday resoundingly rejected the re-election bid of Romes mayor, Virginia Raggi of the Five Star Movement, who swept into power five years ago promising change but was unable to turn around the degradation of services and quality of life that has become a hallmark of the capital.

title: Bubba Wallace Gets a Breakthrough NASCAR Victory at Talladega
description: A little more than a year after almost single-handedly forcing American auto racing to confront the sports longstanding issues with racism, Darrell Wallace Jr., known as Bubba, became just the second Black winner in NASCARs top series, finishing first at a rain-shortened event at Talladega Superspeedway on Monday afternoon.

title: Drake Edged Out of No. 1 Spot by YoungBoy Never Broke Again
description: In a close race for No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, the new release by YoungBoy Never Broke Again, a 21-year-old from Baton Rouge, La., narrowly beat fourth-week sales for Certified Lover Boy, the streaming smash by Drake, who was dethroned after three straight weeks on top.

title: Whats Wrong With Kyrsten Sinema?
description: In 2003, Joe Lieberman, at the time one of the worst Democratic senators, traveled to Arizona to campaign for his partys presidential nomination and was regularly greeted by antiwar demonstrators. Hes a shame to Democrats, said the organizer of a protest outside a Tucson hotel, a left-wing social worker named Kyrsten Sinema. I dont even know why hes running. He seems to want to get Republicans voting for him  what kind of strategy is that?

title: Pandora Papers: A Money Bomb With Political Ripples
description: The headlines thundered: Jordans king amassed $100 million in concealed property including homes in Malibu, London and Washington. An alleged mistress of Russias leader managed to covertly buy a luxury residence in Monaco. The Czech Republics prime minister, an anticorruption crusader, secretly acquired a French Riviera estate.

title: The mayor of Baltimore tests positive for Covid.
description: Mayor Brandon M. Scott of Baltimore tested positive for Covid-19 on Monday despite being vaccinated, his office said.

title: Climate Change Is Devastating Coral Reefs Worldwide, Major Report Says
description: The world lost about 14 percent of its coral reefs in the decade after 2009, mainly because of climate change, according to a sweeping international report on the state of the worlds corals.

title: Show of Love
